awd_titl_txt: GOALI: Enhancing Cartilage Tissue Engineering through Synergistic Influence of Co-Culture, Mechano-Chemical Factors, and 3D Printed Scaffolds in a Novel Centrifugal Bioreactor
awd_abstract_narration:
1606226 
Van Wie, Bernard J.

Cartilage, the smooth tissue at the end of bones, can withstand enormous loads and provides ease of motion in articulating joints. However, when cartilage is damaged due to injury or aging, osteoarthritis develops. Cartilage has a limited ability to regenerate and to date, no treatment capable of restoring its function exists. Osteoarthritis affects many Americans and is on the rise. In this project, a team from Washington State University, Regeneron Pharmaceuticals, Inc., and Morehouse College, a Historically Black College, will use a novel bioreactor housed within a centrifuge that supplies pulses of pressure to simulate loads experienced by knees during walking for growing the tissue.  The project provides enabling technology for the biopharmaceutical industry for manufacturing new tissues for regenerative medicine. Involving African Americans from Morehouse is expected to enhance opportunities for minority undergraduate and PhD students seeking degrees in the burgeoning field of biotechnology.

Articular cartilage (AC), a connective tissue lining moving joints, has a highly ordered structure for withstanding enormous load transfers and a frictionless surface for ease of motion. However, AC is vulnerable to lesions due to injury or aging, leading to osteoarthritis, and has a limited ability to regenerate because it is aneural and avascular. To improve success in regenerating healthy AC, new bioreactors capable of introducing multiple stimuli simultaneously, including oscillating hydrostatic pressures, perfusing with fresh medium containing chondrogenic factors, and culturing in hydrogels and tri-layered constructs, 3D printed with a gradient of cell types and growth factors, are needed. The central hypothesis in this NSF GOALI is that optimal chondrogenesis will occur when strategically combining (1) tissue co-culture of MSCs and AChs at optimum ratios, (2) oscillating hydrostatic pressures to mimic in vivo conditions, accomplished by cultivating in a unique centrifugal bioreactor, (3) growth factor stimulation through use of TGF?Ò1; (4) antioxidant nutraceutical laden hydrogels shown to enhance chondrogenesis by reducing reactive oxygen species, and (5) mimicry of the tri-layered cartilage tissue through biomanufacturing with flow-based direct-ink-writing of 3-D constructs gradated in cell type, mechanical properties and growth factor. Cartilage regenerative medicine for osteoarthritis will be advanced significantly by improved understanding of the complex interplay of co-culture and mechanical and biochemical stimuli needed to create healthy cartilage, and by new protocols that will allow study of the cellular mechanisms involved. Relevant knowledge will be gained by using atomic force microscopy to determine tissue and cellular elastic moduli, and to map cell surface beta1-integrin distributions that are implicated in producing healthy ECM. This information will be combined with histology and mass spectrometry to fully characterize phenotypic expression. Importantly, the GOALI industrial partner, Regeneron Pharmaceuticals, Inc. will play a key role by providing comprehensive companion genotypic information via qRT-PCR and next generation sequencing to differentially assess the presence of chondrogenic versus osteogenic mRNA markers as a function of culture conditions. Finally, new knowledge will be gained about additive manufacturing of composite bio-constructs with mechanical property and material content gradients using novel thermosensitive hydrogels.

This award by the Biotechnology and Biochemical Engineering Program of the CBET Division is co-funded by the Historically Black Colleges and Universities Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP)of the Division of Human Resource Development and by the GOALI Program of the Division of Industrial Innovation and Partnerships.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The broader impact of this National Science Foundation cartilage tissue engineering project relates to treatment of osteoarthritis. Osteoarthritis affects more than 27 million Americans and is projected to increase due to the aging population. This disease degrades the cartilage in the knee, hip and other joints causing inflammation and loss of function. Clinical treatments range from replacing knees or hips with artificial joints, to grafting a patient?s own cartilage-producing cells, to microfracture where a surgeon drills into the bone beneath the cartilage releasing stem cells that generate new tissue. Yet, these methods have limitations. Joint replacements don?t last a lifetime and can lead to infection. Tissues from grafting and microfracture are not robust and degrade with time. An alternative is tissue engineering. With support from the NSF award No. 1606226, our group sought to combine mechanical stress, growth factors, and nutraceuticals to stimulate cartilage manufacture. Cells known as chondrocytes and adult stem cells can be stimulated with stresses and chemicals like those in the body to regenerate healthy cartilage.

Another broader impact goal was to impact underrepresented undergraduates, mentoring them and fostering an atmosphere to promote pursuit of advanced PhD degrees. One African American student from Morehouse College became involved through summer research experience programs. He later entered the PhD program at Washington State University to work on this project. Three female PhD students, one of which has a handicap, were mentored on the project, graduated, and are leading productive careers. Several other female and minority undergraduates received special training and are going on to graduate school or medical programs.

Our intellectual merit goals were to understand what happens when we supply chondrocytes and adult stem cells with growth factor and nutraceuticals while providing stretching and friction from fluid flow across the surface of a gel containing cells. Cells were derived from participant tissues removed during knee replacement surgery. Chondrocytes isolated from osteoarthritic male and female patients responded much differently to nutraceutical treatment suggesting benefits of nutraceuticals are sex dependent. We used nutraceuticals including vitamin E and other antioxidants found in fruits and nuts like gallic acid, ascorbic acid and catechin. After 21 days of culture our results show 62 % (females) and 66 % (males) decreases in reactive oxygen species that lead to inflammation of cartilage in joints. These studies suggest more of an impact of gallic acid for female derived cells and vitamin E for male derived cells. Our studies show chondrocytes from osteoarthritic female patients of differing ages respond differently to nutraceutical treatment. Engineered tissues of younger overweight participants responded better to nutraceuticals than tissues derived from the older but leaner participants. This study suggests excessive weight surpasses age as a risk factor for osteoarthritis. New biocompatible gels made of alginate, gelatin, and gum Arabic enhanced growth of chondrocytes from cattle, and built the pericellular matrix (thin layer surrounding chondrocytes) and the cartilage matrix itself.

We found stretching of cartilage matrix, containing a mix of chondrocytes and adult stem cells, increases properties of the matrix by making more of the key ingredients, collagen and glycan. Stretching plus gallic acid work in synergy, promoting deposit of collagen and glycan in cartilage by 14-fold and 7-fold, respectively. Other cartilage-specific proteins, like collagen 2 and collagen 11 increased by a respective 47-fold and 7-fold, and we found a reduction in genes coding for molecules that degrade cartilage like MMP-1 by 2.5-fold and MMP-13 by 125-fold.

Fluid friction, across gels that contain chondrocytes, increased cell viability and even more so if the gels are porous. We saw a 45-fold increase in collagen when flow is across surfaces only and a 150-fold increase when the gels are porous. The glycan molecule also increased by 13-fold and 2-fold for the respective porous and non-porous gels with flow. Besides that, it appears the right kind of collagen is being made based on the genes for collagen type 2 (more desired) over collagen type 1 (less desired) with a corresponding increase in the correct type of glycan (aggrecan). At the same time, we saw reductions of genes for molecules that cause inflammation and those which degrade cartilage.

The collective results hold promise for future work to enhance cartilage manufacture, potentially for implantation and certainly for understanding the role of mechanical, growth factor and nutraceutical effects in regenerating healthy cartilage. Strategies that include meaningful involvement of underrepresented students on an exciting project like this one will encourage them to pursue advanced education and training.

 


Last Modified: 03/30/2023
Modified by: Bernard J Van Wie

Image
  • Washington State University bioreactor maintains articular cartilage properties for chondrocytes embedded in alginate gel. Animation depicts fluid shear gradients that mimic those in native cartilage. Upper left shows COL2A1 genes are enhanced at shear levels of 2 and 72 mPa.
    Terreill Robertson, Eric Barrow & Bernie Van Wie
    Public Domain
    Bernard J Van Wie
    Bioreactor with shear and collagen 2A1 increases
